S2095-4956(24)00268-7 10.1016/j.jechem.2024.03.056 Science Press Fig. 1 (a) Schematic of the Cu2Se@NC synthesis. FESEM images of the (b–d) Cu2O template and (e, f) Cu2Se@NC. (g, h) TEM and (i) HRTEM images of Cu2Se@NC. (j) SAED pattern. (k) Elemental mapping images of Cu, Se, C, and N. Fig. 2 Phase analysis of Cu2Se@NC. (a) XRD pattern. (b) Raman spectrum. XPS spectra of (c) Cu 2p, (d) Se 3d, (e) C 1s, and (f) N 1s. Fig. 3 The electrochemical properties of Cu2Se@NC in SIBs. (a) CV curves. (b) Charge-discharge profiles at various cycles. (c) Cycling performance at 0.5 A g−1. (d) Differential capacity profiles at different cycles. (e) Charge-discharge profiles at various densities. (f) Rate capability compared with bare Cu2Se. (g) Long-term cyclic stability at 5 and 10 A g−1 compared with bare Cu2Se (10 A g−1). Fig. 4 Mechanism analyses of Cu2Se@NC electrode in SIBs. (a, b) 2D contour plot of in situ XRD. HRTEM and element mapping images at (c, d) 0.3 V and (e, f) 3.0 V of the first cycle. (g) Phase evolution schematic of Cu2Se within discharging/charging. Fig. 5 The electrochemical properties of Cu2Se@NC in PIBs. (a) CV curves. (b) Charge-discharge curves. (c) Cycling performance in comparison of bare Cu2Se at 0.1 A g−1. (d) Differential capacity profiles. (e) Charge-discharge curves. (f) Rate capability in comparison of bare Cu2Se. (g) Cycling performance in comparison of bare Cu2Se at 2 A g−1. Fig. 6 Mechanism analyses of Cu2Se@NC in PIBs. (a) 2D contour plot of in situ XRD patterns collected within the initial cycle. Ex situ HRTEM and element mapping images at the states of (b, d) discharging to 0.1 V and (c, e) charging to 2.5 V. Fig. 7 Kinetic analyses of the Cu2Se@NC electrode. CV curves at varying scan rates in (a) SIBs and (d) PIBs. Capacitive contribution at 0.8 mV s−1 in (b) SIBs and (e) PIBs. The proportions of capacitive and diffusion contributions at varying scan rates in (c) SIBs and (f) PIBs. GITT curves in (g) SIBs and (j) PIBs. The calculated Na+ diffusion coefficients within the (h) discharging and (i) charging processes of the first cycle. The calculated K+ diffusion coefficients within the (k) discharging and (l) charging processes of the first cycle. Fig. 8 (a) The calculated DOS values of Cu2Se and Cu2Se@NC. (b) PDOS of Cu-3d orbitals for Cu2Se and Cu2Se@NC. (c) The calculated electrostatic potential for Cu2Se and carbon. (d) 2D section of electron density difference distribution of the heterostructure. (e) Top- and side-view of the diffusion pathway of Na+ (yellow ball) and K+ (purple) of Case I and (f) the corresponding energy barriers for Na+ and K+ migration. (g) Top- and side-view of the diffusion pathway of Na+ and K+ of Case II and (h) the corresponding energy barriers of Na+ and K+ migration. Fig. 9 Side- and top-view of a single (a) Na+ and (b) K+ adsorbed (I) above the carbon, (II–IV) on different positions of the interface between carbon and Cu2Se, (V) in the Cu2Se bulk nearby the interface, and (VI) in the Cu2Se bulk away from the interface, as well as the corresponding adsorption energies. Graphical abstract The unique nanocubic structure and uniform N-doped carbon coating shorten the ion transport distance and suppress volume variation. Furthermore, the higher diffusion kinetics and reaction activity endow Cu2Se@NC with better electrochemical properties in SIBs than PIBs. The large volumetric variations experienced by metal selenides within conversion reaction result in inferior rate capability and cycling stability, ultimately hindering the achievement of superior electrochemical performance. Herein, metallic Cu2Se encapsulated with N-doped carbon (Cu2Se@NC) was prepared using Cu2O nanocubes as templates through a combination of dopamine polymerization and high-temperature selenization. The unique nanocubic structure and uniform N-doped carbon coating could shorten the ion transport distance, accelerate electron/charge diffusion, and suppress volume variation, ultimately ensuring Cu2Se@NC with excellent electrochemical performance in sodium ion batteries (SIBs) and potassium ion batteries (PIBs). The composite exhibited excellent rate performance (187.7 mA h g−1 at 50 A g−1 in SIBs and 179.4 mA h g−1 at 5 A g−1 in PIBs) and cyclic stability (246.8 mA h g−1 at 10 A g−1 in SIBs over 2500 cycles). The reaction mechanism of intercalation combined with conversion in both SIBs and PIBs was disclosed by in situ X-ray diffraction (XRD) and ex situ transmission electron microscope (TEM). In particular, the final products in PIBs of K2Se and K2Se3 species were determined after discharging, which is different from that in SIBs with the final species of Na2Se. The density functional theory calculation showed that carbon induces strong coupling and charge interactions with Cu2Se, leading to the introduction of built-in electric field on heterojunction to improve electron mobility. Significantly, the theoretical calculations discovered that the underlying cause for the relatively superior rate capability in SIBs to that in PIBs is the agile Na+ diffusion with low energy barrier and moderate adsorption energy. These findings offer theoretical support for in-depth understanding of the performance differences of Cu-based materials in different ion storage systems. Keywords Cu2Se nanocubes DFT calculations Ion storage mechanism Potassium ion batteries Sodium ion batteries 1 Introduction Nowadays, reducing greenhouse gas emissions and improving air quality have become the common goals of all mankind [1,2]. The emerging energy systems, such as hydropower, wind power, and solar energy, cannot be widely applied to long-term and regular storage due to geographical and time constraints [3,4]. Lithium ion batteries (LIBs), as one of the most popular energy storage technologies, play a central role in reducing carbon dioxide emissions from vehicle transportation and power grids [5,6]. Although LIBs have many advantages and are mature commercial systems, the lithium resource shortage and high cost limit their large-scale applications [7]. Sodium ion batteries (SIBs) and potassium ion batteries (PIBs) are regarded as potential substitutes for LIBs due to the abundance and cheapness of sodium and potassium resources [8–10]. However, the reaction kinetics is relatively slow because of the large repulsive force generated during intercalation/de-intercalation of Na+/K+ with larger radius. Therefore, the development of suitable SIBs and PIBs electrodes is a key challenge in achieving high-performance energy storage systems [11]. Among the various anode materials [4,12–15], transition metal selenides have been proved to be one kind of the most attractive candidates in SIBs and PIBs because of low cost, high theoretical capacity, large tap density, and high reaction activity stemming from weak M−Se bond, endowing them with satisfactory electrochemical properties [16]. As an important p-type semiconductor, the pollution-free Cu2Se possesses many advantages, including good structural stability, high electrical conductivity, and small volume fluctuation in Na+/K+ intercalation and deintercalation [17,18]. In terms of the structure of Cu2Se, Cu atoms are closely arranged between the Se atomic layers, exhibiting a layered structure formed through a relatively weak Se–Se bond, which is beneficial for the ion intercalation and deintercalation in lattice [19]. Nevertheless, the electrochemical performance of Cu2Se in SIBs and PIBs is still unsatisfactory to achieve high performance, which requires the further research. From another perspective, the electrolyte optimization plays a crucial role in ensuring high ion storage capability, stability, and safety. Therefore, for the Cu2Se anode, it is urgently necessary to select an appropriate electrolyte that possesses the capabilities of forming a stable and robust solid electrolyte interface (SEI) layer, suppressing decomposition within the operating voltage window, and minimizing undesirable side reactions [20–25]. Herein, a Cu2Se@NC nanocomposite was designed and fabricated by the polymerization of the dopamine hydrochloride coated on the nanosized Cu2O cubes precursor via a wet chemical method and a following calcination treatment. The merits of the Cu2Se@NC nanocomposite are as follows: (i) the unique nanocubic structure reduces the ion diffusion distance and enlarges the contact area between electrolyte and active material, promoting the Na+/K+ migration; (ii) the modification of nitrogen-doped carbon layer coated on the surface of Cu2Se can not only improve its conductivity, but also avoid the structure collapse caused by the repeated insertion/extraction of Na+/K+, and thus sustains the structural integrity. Meanwhile, the nitrogen-doped sites can provide more storage sites for Na+/K+; (iii) the high conductive metallic Cu produced within the conversion reaction will serve as a conductor, which could further promote the reaction activity. Benefiting from the above-mentioned structural merits, Cu2Se@NC composite showed excellent rate and cycling performance as expected when used as the SIBs/PIBs anode material. The electrolytes for SIBs and PIBs were optimized for the purpose of achieving superior performance. Moreover, the intercalation and conversion sodium/potassium storage mechanisms of Cu2Se@NC and the corresponding kinetic properties were explored in detail by comprehensive in situ/ex situ electrochemical characterizations and theoretical calculations. 2 Experimental 2.1 Sample preparation 2.1.1 Synthesis of Cu2O nanocubes Sodium citrate solution (0.2 mol L−1) was added to a three-necked flask with 400 mL of deionized water. After stirring for 20 min, copper sulfate, sodium hydroxide, and ascorbic acid were added to the above mixture every 5 min under stirring. After 30 min, Cu2O was harvested by centrifugation and rinsing before drying. 2.1.2 Synthesis of Cu2O@PDA nanocubes 100 mg of as-prepared Cu2O nanocubes were first dispersed into 100 mL (0.1 M) of tris-buffer solution by ultrasound, and then 50 mg of dopamine hydrochloride was added and stirred for 10 h. The resulting product was centrifugally collected, washed, and dried. 2.1.3 Synthesis of Cu2Se@NC nanoparticle 100 mg Se powder was loaded into an alumina boat which was placed at the center of the upstream zone of the furnace, while another alumina boat containing 50 mg Cu2O@PDA nanocubes was placed at the downstream zone. The sample was heated to 300 °C for 2 h and then to 600 °C for 3 h with a rate of 2 °C min−1 to obtain the final Cu2Se@NC nanoparticles. For comparison, Cu2Se nanoparticles were synthesized using the same method without polydopamine (PDA) coating and the following annealing treatment. 2.2 Materials characterization The acquired electrode materials were characterized using X-ray diffraction (XRD, D8 X-ray diffractometer with Cu-K α radiation), field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM, JEOL JMS-6700F), and transmission electron microscope (TEM, JEOL JEM-2010F). Carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen, and sulfur (CHNS) elemental analysis (Thermo Flash EA 1112, USA) was used to evaluate the carbon content in Cu2Se@NC. The AXIS Supra Imaging X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS, Kratos Analytical Ltd. U.K.) was applied to analyze the element states. Raman spectra were recorded with a Labram high resolution spectrometer. 2.3 Electrochemical measurements The active material, acetylene black, and sodium carboxymethyl cellulose (mass ratio of 7: 2: 1) were mixed and ground uniformly with an appropriate amount of ultrapure water to prepare the working electrode, and the slurry was pasted onto copper foil. The average loading mass for each electrode in both SIBs and PIBs ranged between 0.8 and 1.1 mg cm−2. To prepare the cathode slurry for the full cells, commercial Na3V2(PO4)3, acetylene black, and polyvinylidene difluoride in a ratio of 8:1:1 were dispersed in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidene, and the as-obtained slurry was uniformly coated on aluminum foils. The mass loading was approximately 2.7 mg cm−2. The applied electrolytes are 1 M NaCF3SO3 in diglyme for SIBs and 1 M KFSI in dimethoxyethane (DME) for PIBs, and the electrolyte dosage is about 100 μL. Glass microfiber filter (Whatman GF/D) was used as the membrane for the half and full cells. The electrochemical performance was measured on the LAND CT2001A multi-channel battery testing system. Biologic VSP-300 electrochemical workstation was utilized to conduct the cyclic voltammograms (CV) and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements. 3 Results and discussion Fig. 1 (a) shows the synthesis scheme from the brick red Cu2O nanocubes to PDA-coated Cu2O intermediate (Cu2O@PDA) prepared by means of dopamine polymerization, and finally to N-doped carbon coated Cu2Se nanocubes after pyrolysis and selenization treatments. As displayed in Fig. 1(b–i), the structural characteristics of the Cu2O precursor and Cu2Se@NC composite were analyzed via FESEM and TEM). The FESEM images exhibit the uniform cubic structure of the Cu2O precursor with a size of about 90 nm (Fig. 1b–d). In the FESEM image with high magnification (Fig. 1d), it can be found that the surface of the Cu2O template is relatively smooth. After pyrolysis and selenization treatments, the irregular shape of Cu2Se@NC nanoparticles can be observed in Fig. 1(e and f). The FESEM images of the bare Cu2Se reference sample are displayed in Fig. S1. As shown in Fig. 1(g), the TEM image identifies that Cu2Se@NC nanoparticle kept the cubic nanostructure after carbon coating. The nanosized distribution of Cu2Se@NC is believed to speed up the electrolyte penetration and offer abundant active sites to store Na+/K+. Furthermore, the nitrogen adsorption-desorption tests were conducted for both Cu2Se@NC and bare Cu2Se to determine the surface area, as shown in Fig. S2. In the TEM image in Fig. 1(h), it can be deduced that the thickness of carbon layer in Cu2Se@NC is about 15 nm. Moderate carbon layer can not only effectively alleviate the volume change within cycling to sustain the structural stability, but also enhance the conductivity of the electrode material. The high resolution TEM (HRTEM) image of the composite is shown in Fig. 1(i), in which the lattice fringes with spacing of 0.332 nm correspond to the (111) plane of Cu2Se. Fig. 1(j) shows the selected area electron diffraction (SAED) image with the diffraction rings indexing to (111), (220), and (311) planes of Cu2Se, confirming the polycrystallinity of Cu2Se. The element distribution images (Fig. 1k) show the distribution of Cu, Se, C, and N elements across the Cu2Se@NC composite, indicating the uniform coating of N-doped carbon layer on Cu2Se. The structure of the obtained Cu2O precursor, Cu2Se@NC composite, and Cu2Se reference sample were analyzed by XRD measurement. Fig. S3(a) is the XRD pattern of Cu2O precursor, and the diffraction peaks are indexed well to the cubic phase Cu2O (JCPDS card no. 05-0667). After high temperature selenization and carbonization treatments, the peaks of the final Cu2Se@NC composite are assigned to Cu2Se (JCPDS card no. 65-2982) with cubic phase, as shown in Fig. 2 (a). In the Raman spectrum of Cu2Se@NC in Fig. 2(b), the peak located at 1320 cm−1 corresponds to D-band caused by disordered structure, while the peak at 1590 cm−1 corresponds to the G-band stemming from graphite characteristic. An I D/I G value of 0.83 suggests a defective structure of the carbon layer in the composite [26,27]. The elemental analysis displayed in Fig. S4(b) confirmed 14% carbon in the composite. The valence states of elements in Cu2Se@NC were clarified by the utilization of XPS, and the survey spectrum is shown in Fig. S5. The peaks at 932.4 and 952.3 eV in the spectrum of Cu 2p (Fig. 2c) are attributed to Cu 2p 3/2 and Cu 2p 1/2 of Cu+ in Cu2Se, respectively [19,26,27]. The peaks at 933.7 and 954.8 eV are connected with surface oxidation, belonging to Cu 2p 3/2 and Cu 2p 1/2 of Cu2+, respectively [19,28]. In addition, the satellite characteristic peaks of Cu2+ are located at 944.0 and 962.8 eV [19]. The Se 3d spectrum is shown in Fig. 2(d), in which the doublet peaks at 53.7 and 54.6 eV are attributed to Se 3d 5/2 and Se 3d 3/2 of Se2−, respectively [19]. Two peaks at 54.2 and 55.3 eV may refer to the intermediate state of polyselenides with higher valence than −2 [29]. The peaks at 284.7, 285.9, and 288.6 eV in C 1s spectrum (Fig. 2e) are assigned to C–C/C=C, C–N, and C=N, respectively [30–32]. The XPS spectrum of N 1s (Fig. 2f) can be fitted into peaks assigned to pyridinic N at 398.1 eV, pyrrolic N at 400.2 eV, and graphitic N at 402.4 eV [32,33]. CV curves are displayed in Fig. 3 (a). Within the initial discharging process, the peaks at 1.75 V and 1.58 V are assigned to the stepwise intercalation reactions of Na+ into Cu2Se, leading to the formation of Na x Cu2Se [19,28,34,35]. The two peaks at 1.46 and 0.76 V represent the further intercalation and conversion reactions and the generation of SEI layer [19,35]. Within charging, the peaks at 1.4, 1.68, and 1.89 V are indexed to the reverse conversion reaction between Cu and Na2Se to restore Cu2Se [19,34,35]. The CV curves of the subsequent cycles coincided well, indicating a high reversibility of Cu2Se@NC after the first cycle. A very slight shift of the CV curves to lower voltages with increasing cycles can be found after the initial cycle, which may be related to a partial phase transformation into CuSe. Fig. 3(b) exhibits the galvanostatic charge-discharge profiles of the 1st, 2nd, 10th, 50th, 100th, and 150th cycle at 0.5 A g−1. The voltage plateaus in the charge-discharge profiles are associated with the redox peak positions in the CV curves shown in Fig. 3(a). The cycling performance of Cu2Se@NC at 0.5 A g−1 is displayed in Fig. 3(c). After 150 cycles, the capacity still maintained at 322 mA h g−1 with a high-capacity retention of 94.1%. Furthermore, the FESEM images of the Cu2Se@NC electrode after cycles are shown in Fig. S6. It is clearly found that the electrode structure remained intact without obvious agglomeration and pulverization. The differential capacity profiles at different cycles are depicted in Fig. 3(d), and the peaks correspond to the voltage plateaus shown in Fig. 3(a). Fig. 3(e) and Fig. S7 show the charge-discharge curves of Cu2Se@NC and Cu2Se at the 5th cycle of each current density in the range of 0.1–50 A g−1, respectively, and the voltage platforms became less distinct with the rising of current density. The rate performance of Cu2Se@NC compared with bare Cu2Se at different current densities is displayed in Fig. 3(f). Especially noteworthy is that the average specific capacity at 50 A g−1 of Cu2Se@NC electrode is as high as 187.7 mA h g−1. Fig. 3(g) and Fig. S8 compare the ultralong-term cycling properties of the Cu2Se@NC and Cu2Se electrodes at 5 and 10 A g−1, respectively. The Cu2Se@NC electrode maintained high specific capacities of 288.6 mA h g−1 after 1400 cycles at 5 A g−1 and 246.8 mA h g−1 after 2500 cycles at a relatively high current density of 10 A g−1. However, the specific capacity of the bare Cu2Se electrode became unstable after 1000 cycles at a relatively high current density of 10 A g−1, achieving a value of 160.4 mA h g−1 after 2000 cycles, which can be ascribed to the severe pulverization of Cu2Se without the protection of carbon coating. Fig. S9 compares the rate and cycling performance of Cu2Se@NC samples coated with different amounts of dopamine hydrochloride. The results indicate that the best performance is achieved using 50 mg of dopamine hydrochloride. To emphasize the influence of electrolytes on electrochemical performance, Fig. S10 shows the electrochemical performance of different electrolytes. Fig. S11 presents a performance comparison between Cu2Se@NC and reported SIBs anodes. Additionally, to validate the practical application potential of Cu2Se@NC, a full cell with Na3V2(PO4)3/C was constructed, as shown in Fig. S12. The tests demonstrate that the Cu2Se@NC||Na3V2(PO4)3/C full cell exhibited good rate performance and high cycling stability over 300 cycles. The reaction mechanism and structural evolution of Cu2Se@NC electrode in SIBs were investigated by in situ XRD measurement. Fig. 4 (a and b) shows the in situ XRD patterns recorded within 20°–45°. In the pristine state, the peak at 26.8° is ascribed to Cu2Se (JCPDS card no. 65-2982). As the sodiation progressed, the peak of Cu2Se disappeared and two peaks at 25.3° and 40.8° were detected, which are indexed to NaCuSe (JCPDS card no. 71-1820) as a product of intercalation reaction. Within the further discharging course, the peak of NaCuSe disappeared with the emerging of peaks indexed to Na2Se (JCPDS card no. 23-0527) at 22.6° and 37.5° and Cu at 43.5° (JCPDS card no. 01-1241), indicating that the further conversion reaction occurred. Within charging, the peaks of Na2Se and Cu gradually weakened and disappeared with the re-detected peak of NaCuSe shown in the XRD pattern. In the end part of desodiation, the peak of Cu2Se reappeared. Fig. S13 displays the variation in charge transfer resistance (R ct) values obtained through in situ EIS and EIS tests conducted at different cycles in SIBs. Moreover, the HRTEM images of Cu2Se@NC at discharged state of 0.3 V and charged states of 3.0 V are shown in Fig. 4(c and e), respectively. For the state of 0.3 V, the detected lattice distance of 0.184 and 0.248 nm is indexed to (200) plane of Cu and (220) plane of Na2Se, respectively. When the cell was charged to 3.0 V, the lattice distance of 0.334 nm corresponds to the (111) plane of the regenerated Cu2Se. Fig. 4(d and f) is the elemental mapping images of Cu, Se, Na, N, and C elements at 0.3 and 3.0 V, respectively. It is worth noting that the existence of Na after charging refers to the sodium-based components in the formed SEI layer. Based on the above analyses, a phase evolution of Cu2Se within discharging/charging in SIBs is illustrated in Fig. 4(g), showing the following reaction mechanism of Cu2Se@NC. C u 2 S e + x N a + ↔ N a x C u 2 S e N a x C u 2 S e + ( 1 - x ) N a + + ( 1 - x ) e - ↔ N a C u S e + C u N a C u S e + N a + + e - ↔ N a 2 S e + C u Inspired by the excellent properties in sodium ion storage, the electrochemical performance in PIBs of Cu2Se@NC was further studied. The CV curves for the initial five cycles are displayed in Fig. 5 (a). In the first cathodic scan, the two peaks located at 0.66 and 0.46 V refer to the K+ intercalation into the lattice of Cu2Se and the occurrence of conversion reaction with the products of Cu and K x Se [35,36]. During the initial anodic process, a series of redox peaks appeared within 1.5–2.1 V, representing the multiple depotassiation processes, including the reverse conversion reaction (1.51 V) and deintercalation reaction of K+ (1.75 and 2.04 V). Notably, the shift of the redox peak in the subsequent curves could be related to some irreversible microstructural transformation, reactions on the surface or at the interface, or severer polarization [37–39]. Fig. 5(b) displays the charge-discharge curves of the first three cycles, and the platforms are consistent with the redox peak positions in CV curves. The delivered initial discharge and charge capacities of Cu2Se@NC are 444.2 and 281.7 mA h g−1, respectively, showing an initial Coulombic efficiency of 63.4%. The cycling performance of Cu2Se@NC and bare Cu2Se is presented in Fig. 5(c). After 80 cycles, a specific capacity of 287.3 mA h g−1 was acquired at 0.1 A g−1 for the Cu2Se@NC composite. On the contrary, Cu2Se reference sample showed a poor performance with rapid capacity decay within first ten cycles, delivering a capacity of only 39.7 mA h g−1 over 60 cycles. The differential capacity profiles of Cu2Se@NC at the 5th, 15th, and 25th cycle are shown in Fig. 5(d). The fewer peaks in the profiles can be attributed to the less distinct voltage plateaus in the charge-discharge curves compared with that in SIBs system. Fig. 5(e) and Fig. S14 show the charge-discharge curves of Cu2Se@NC and bare Cu2Se electrodes at different current densities, respectively, showing the gradually indistinct voltage plateaus with the increase of current density. Fig. 5(f) compares the rate performance in the range of 0.1 to 5 A g−1 of Cu2Se@NC electrode and Cu2Se reference sample. For Cu2Se@NC, when the current density was stepwise raised from 0.1 to 2 A g−1, the capacities of 281.4, 266.6, 258.3, 244.3, and 223.1 mA h g−1 were harvested. A reversible capacity was reached to 179.4 mA h g−1 under a relatively high density of 5 A g−1. When the current density came back to 0.1 A g−1, the capacity recovered to 291.7 mA h g−1. Nevertheless, Cu2Se showed a poor rate capability, delivering only a capacity of 6.3 mA h g−1 at 5 A g−1. Fig. 5(g) displays the higher capacity and cyclic stability of Cu2Se@NC than that of bare Cu2Se at 2 A g−1. After 150 cycles, the capacities of Cu2Se@NC and bare Cu2Se were 200.6 and 35.3 mA h g−1, respectively, with a capacity retention of 94.4% for Cu2Se@NC. Fig. S15 shows the cycling performance of Cu2Se@NC at 0.5 A g−1 in PIBs using the electrolyte of 5 M KFSI in DME. The FESEM image of Cu2Se@NC electrode after 150 cycles (2 A g−1) is shown in Fig. S16, indicating the protection effect of the carbon coating layer on restraining the large structural variation. The phase change of Cu2Se upon K+ intercalation/de-intercalation was systematically investigated by in situ XRD and ex situ HRTEM. The two-dimensional (2D) contour plot of in situ XRD patterns of Cu2Se in a live PIB is shown in Fig. 6 (a). The peak at 26.8° at the pristine state refers to Cu2Se (JCPDS card no. 65-2982). As the potassiation proceeded, this Cu2Se peak obviously shifted to the left, which was caused by the lattice expansion with K+ insertion into Cu2Se. In the process of further discharging, the peak of Cu2Se gradually faded with the appearance of two new peaks. These emerging peaks at 38.6° and 41.9° are assigned to the (311) plane of K2Se (JCPDS card no. 77-2153) and (042) plane of K2Se3 (JCPDS card no. 71-0235), respectively. Of particular concern is that the peak of Cu2Se was not distinguished at the charged state to 2.5 V owing to the low crystallinity after charging. Fig. S17 displays the variation in R ct values obtained through in-situ EIS and EIS tests conducted at different cycles in PIBs. In the HRTEM image for the electrode at the discharged state of 0.1 V, the lattice fringe with spacing of 0.21 nm is indexed to (110) plane of Cu, while the lattice fringe with distances of 0.27 and 0.32 nm correspond to K2Se ((220) plane, JCPDS card no. 77-2153) and K2Se3 ((112) plane, JCPDS card no. 71-0235), respectively (Fig. 6b). The lattice spacing of 0.30 nm in HRTEM image at fully charged state is associated with the (200) plane of cubic Cu2Se (Fig. 6c), which is additional evidence to confirm the reversibility of Cu2Se. Fig. 6(d and e) presents the elemental distribution mapping images of Cu, Se, C, N, and K at the states of 0.1 and 2.5 V, respectively. Similarly, the existence of K after charging is related to the potassium-based inorganic component in the generated SEI layer. According to the analyses above, the reaction mechanism of Cu2Se@NC in PIBs can be deduced as following. x K + + C u 2 S e ↔ K x C u 2 S e K x C u 2 S e ↔ 2 C u + K y S e ( K 2 S e a n d K 2 S e 3 ) Considering the difference of electrochemical performance of Cu2Se@NC in SIBs and PIBs systems, the reaction kinetics of Cu2Se@NC was studied by CV at varying scan rates and galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT). As shown in Fig. 7 (a and d), the CV curves in SIBs present distinct redox peaks, while those in PIBs show broad peaks, indicating the higher polarization and slow kinetics in PIBs. The percentage of capacitive contribution at each fixed voltage can be quantitatively calculated by i = k 1 v + k 2 v 0.5, where k 1 v is assigned to the capacitive fraction and k 2 v 0.5 represents the diffusion part [40]. The proportions of the capacitive contribution to the total stored capacity are up to 95.1% in SIBs (Fig. 7b) and 90.6% in PIBs (Fig. 7e). Fig. 7(c and f) summarizes the capacitance contribution proportions at various scan rates in SIBs and PIBs, respectively. It can be found that the sodium storage is dominated by the capacitance behavior under all the scan rates. By contrast, the diffusion and capacitive contributions play equal parts at low rate in PIBs, and the capacitive participation shows rapid increase with the rising of scan rate. The discharge-charge curves of Cu2Se and Cu2Se@NC electrodes measured by GITT are shown in Fig. 7(g) (SIBs) and Fig. 7(j) (PIBs). Fig. 7(h and i) respectively compares the sodium ion diffusion coefficient ( D N a + ) values of bare Cu2Se and Cu2Se@NC within the first cycle calculated by the equation: D = 4 π τ n m V m s 2 Δ E s Δ E t 2 [41]. The obvious D N a + drop might be caused by the Na+ migration through the interphase boundary required to overcome the resistance from the surrounding ions [42,43]. Obviously, Cu2Se@NC has higher D N a + values than Cu2Se, which can be attributed to the interconnection of carbon layers to generate a three-dimensional conductive framework that accelerates the transport of electrons and ions. Fig. 7(k and l) presents the potassium ion diffusion coefficient ( D K + ) values of Cu2Se@NC within the first cycle, also showing higher D K + values than that of Cu2Se. By comparison, it can be found that D N a + values are higher than D K + values in both discharging and charging processes, which is the one of the reasons for the electrochemical performance difference of Cu2Se@NC between in SIBs and PIBs that further theoretical investigation is needed. The density functional theory (DFT) calculation was resorted to dig into electric structure and reaction kinetics of the Cu2Se@NC and bare Cu2Se in both SIBs and PIBs. The density of states (DOS) was calculated to prove the metallic nature of Cu2Se and uncover the effect of carbon coating on the electrical conductivity. As shown in Fig. 8 (a) and Fig. S18, the occupied Fermi levels by the electron orbitals manifest the metallic characteristics of bare Cu2Se and Cu2Se@NC, respectively [44,45]. In contrast, the contributions of Cu 3d and Se 2p in Cu2Se@NC are greater than those in bare Cu2Se, indicating that the carbon induces the coupling between Cu and Se and charge interaction, and thus increases DOS values around the Fermi Level. The band structure change was acquired using the partial density of states (PDOS) of d-band, as shown in Fig. 8(b). The calculated d-band center for bare Cu2Se is −2.209 eV. For the Cu2Se@NC, the PDOS displays distinct splitting coupling of d-orbital, which is reflected in the upward shifting of d-band center to −2.195 eV, rendering a stronger adsorption of Na+ on the composite [46,47]. As shown in Fig. 8(c), the calculated values of work function are 5.47 and 4.26 eV for Cu2Se and carbon, respectively. The lower value of carbon induces the electron drifting to Cu2Se, leading to the formation of negative (around Cu2Se) and positive (around carbon) space charge regions. This discrepancy produces a built-in electric field generated on heterointerface directed to Cu2Se from carbon, which is conducive to the improvement in electron migration [48]. Fig. 8(d) displays the 2D section of differential charge density distribution on Cu2Se-NC heterointerface for the sake of illustrating the transferring tendency of electrons by the green and red regions representing the charge accumulation and depletion, respectively. The distribution of differential charge density also suggests a carrier following from carbon to Cu2Se in obedience to the balance of Fermi levels. The generated built-in electric field on the heterointerface and the tendency of directional electron transfer lead to an increased electrical conductivity, which is consistent with the results of better rate capability of Cu2Se@NC than the bare Cu2Se in both SIBs (Fig. 3f) and PIBs (Fig. 5f) systems. The better electrochemical performance of Cu2Se@NC in SIBs than that in PIBs prompts the exploration for the underlying reasons by comparing the migration energy barriers of Na+ and K+ with different diffusion paths on the Cu2Se-NC heterointerface. The top-view and side-view of the selected ion migration paths are shown in Fig. 8(e and g). As displayed in Fig. S19, the energy barriers of Na+ on bare Cu2Se in Case I and Case II are 0.289 and 0.669 eV, respectively. Compared with that on bare Cu2Se, the energy barriers of Na+ and K+ on Cu2Se@NC heterointerface in both Case I and Case II are reduced, indicating that the heterojunction interface is conducive to the Na+ and K+ migration (Fig. 8f and h). Importantly, the decreasing in energy barriers of Na+ (0.21 eV for Case I and 0.519 eV for Case II) is greater than that of K+ (0.285 eV for Case I and 0.62 eV for Case II), suggesting that the heterointerface has a major impact on the facile migration of Na+ (The decline in energy barriers of K+ is relatively small). This accounts for the calculated larger D N a + values in SIBs (Fig. 7h and i) than D K + values in PIBs (Fig. 7k and l) during both discharging and charging processes. Moreover, the average layer spacing after the intercalation of Na+ and K+ is 3.37 and 3.94 Å, respectively, as shown in Fig. S20. It can be deduced that the adsorption of K+ will cause larger volume expansion, explaining the difficulty of K+ migration in Cu2Se@NC and poor electrochemical performance in PIBs than that in SIBs. Furthermore, for the Case I, the energy barriers for Na+ and K+ migration are relatively small compared with Case II. Thus, Case I is the preferred diffusion path for both Na+ and K+, considering the less a half of the relative energy than that for Case II. In addition, the varying adsorption sites simulating ion migration cross the Cu2Se-NC junction region are shown in Fig. 9 , namely adsorbed above the carbon (I), on different positions of the interface between carbon and Cu2Se (II–IV), in the Cu2Se bulk nearby the interface (V), and in the Cu2Se bulk away from the interface (VI). Fig. S21 shows side- and top-view of a single Na+ and K+ adsorbed on the different positions of bare Cu2Se with the corresponding adsorption energies. The above calculated results of d-band center (Fig. 8b) indicate the construction of interface would induce the strong adsorption of Na+. As a result, it can be observed that the adsorption energy has the smallest value, for both Na+ and K+, at the heterojunction interface between Cu2Se and carbon, signifying that the heterojunction interface is not only beneficial to the migration of Na+ and K+, but is also conducive to the ion adsorption as the active sites. Notably, the absolute values of adsorption energies for K+ at varying positions are larger than those for Na+, which might result in the arduous desorption for K+ during the transfer process. This could explain the sluggish K+ migration with larger energy barriers in Case I and Case II and less capacitive contribution in PIBs (Fig. 7d–f) than in SIBs (Fig. 7a–c). Combined with the calculation results of electric structure and kinetics properties, the better sodium storage performance than potassium is illustrated. 4 Conclusions In this study, a Cu2Se@NC composite was successfully prepared by in situ selenium-carbonization method. The nanosized structure of the as-prepared Cu2Se@NC composite increased the electrolyte contact and promoted the ion migration. The modification of N-doped carbon coating effectively improved the electrical conductivity, alleviated the volume expansion/shrinkage, and thus protected the integrity of the structure. Thanks to the above advantages, Cu2Se@NC composite presented superior cycling and rate properties in SIBs, delivering specific capacities of 322 mA h g−1 after 150 cycles at 0.5 A g−1 and 246.8 mA h g−1 over 2500 cycles at 10 A g−1. Astonishingly, a specific capacity of 187.7 mA h g−1 was achieved at an ultrahigh current density of 50 A g−1. Furthermore, the sodium ion full battery pairing the Cu2Se@NC with Na3V2(PO4)3/C as cathode was verified to realize good rate performance and high cyclic stability over 300 cycles. In PIBs system, a high capacity of 200.6 mA h g−1 was maintained over 150 cycles at 2 A g−1. Significantly, in situ XRD and ex situ TEM measurements revealed the different conversion reaction mechanisms of Cu2Se@NC in SIBs and PIBs by the detection of different products after discharging. Furthermore, GITT and in situ EIS tests combined with DFT calculations interpret the intrinsic reasons for the difference in Na+/K+ diffusion kinetics at the Cu2Se-NC heterointerface. coredata.dc:description: The large volumetric variations experienced by metal selenides within conversion reaction result in inferior rate capability and cycling stability, ultimately hindering the achievement of superior electrochemical performance. Herein, metallic Cu2Se encapsulated with N-doped carbon (Cu2Se@NC) was prepared using Cu2O nanocubes as templates through a combination of dopamine polymerization and high-temperature selenization. The unique nanocubic structure and uniform N-doped carbon coating could shorten the ion transport distance, accelerate electron/charge diffusion, and suppress volume variation, ultimately ensuring Cu2Se@NC with excellent electrochemical performance in sodium ion batteries (SIBs) and potassium ion batteries (PIBs). The composite exhibited excellent rate performance (187.7 mA h g−1 at 50 A g−1 in SIBs and 179.4 mA h g−1 at 5 A g−1 in PIBs) and cyclic stability (246.8 mA h g−1 at 10 A g−1 in SIBs over 2500 cycles). The reaction mechanism of intercalation combined with conversion in both SIBs and PIBs was disclosed by in situ X-ray diffraction (XRD) and ex situ transmission electron microscope (TEM). In particular, the final products in PIBs of K2Se and K2Se3 species were determined after discharging, which is different from that in SIBs with the final species of Na2Se. The density functional theory calculation showed that carbon induces strong coupling and charge interactions with Cu2Se, leading to the introduction of built-in electric field on heterojunction to improve electron mobility. Significantly, the theoretical calculations discovered that the underlying cause for the relatively superior rate capability in SIBs to that in PIBs is the agile Na+ diffusion with low energy barrier and moderate adsorption energy. These findings offer theoretical support for in-depth understanding of the performance differences of Cu-based materials in different ion storage systems.
